$BTC  at $77K Could Be the Deepest Pullback of the Bull Run   $BTC  dropped 7% to $77,000 on Saturday before recovering slightly to $78,690 by end of day, according to CoinMarketCap. The move added to an 11.44% monthly decline, leaving the asset roughly 38% below its all-time high of $126,100, reached on Oct. 5.  #Bitcoin  analyst PlanC posted on X on Saturday that the dip could mark the bottom of this bull cycle. He compared the current #sell-off  to three prior episodes where $BTC  found a floor and reversed: the 2018 bear market #bottom  near $3,000, the March 2020 crash to around $5,100, and the post-FTX decline to roughly $15,500. "Decent chance this will be the deepest pullback opportunity this Bitcoin bull run," PlanC wrote.  PlanC placed the likely range for the cycle bottom between $75,000 and $80,000. If that reading holds, Saturday's low lands squarely within that window, framing it as a potential accumulation point for traders willing to buy into weakness.  Financial accountant and $BTC  advocate Rajat Soni pushed back against that reading on X, urging traders to avoid reacting to weekend price action. "Never trust a weekend pump OR dump," Soni wrote, adding that $BTC  tends to stage recoveries when sentiment is at its most bearish. His warning came as the market was processing over $2 billion in #liquidations .  Veteran trader Peter Brandt has taken a more cautious stance, predicting that $BTC  could fall to as low as $60,000 by Q3 2026. Analyst Benjamin Cowen expects the true cycle #low  to arrive in early October but noted he "anticipates plenty of rallies will occur between now and then."  Jurrien Timmer, Fidelity's director of global macroeconomic research, described 2026 as a possible "year off" for $BTC , with prices potentially dropping to $65,000 before any sustained recovery takes shape.   The range of forecasts is unusually wide right now.

Bitcoin Sell-Off Pushes IBIT Investor Returns Into the Red   Aggregate dollar-weighted returns for investors in BlackRock's iShares #Bitcoin  Trust have turned negative, according to Bob Elliott, chief investment officer at asset manager Unlimited Funds. Elliott posted a chart on X tracking cumulative performance, which showed returns dipping below zero as of late January after $BTC  slid into the mid-$70,000 range.  The negative figure does not mean every #IBIT  holder is underwater. Investors who bought in early at lower prices likely still hold a gain. The problem is that the fund attracted enormous inflows at much higher price levels later in the year, and those purchases have pulled the overall dollar-weighted average into the red. On a per-dollar-invested basis, cumulative gains since the fund's launch have now been erased, Elliott's data showed.   IBIT's dollar-weighted returns peaked at roughly $35 billion in October, when $BTC  was trading near record highs. The fund remains one of BlackRock's most successful launches, having become the fastest #ETF  in history to reach $70 billion in assets under management. In October, it generated approximately $25 million more in fees than #BlackRock 's second-most profitable ETF, according to reports at the time.   Yahoo Finance data confirms that IBIT's net asset value has been declining for several weeks, tracking closely with the broader $BTC  sell-off. That erosion in underlying value is what has pushed aggregate investor returns into negative territory.   Outflows from $BTC  investment products have been accelerating alongside the price decline. In the week ending Jan. 25, $BTC  funds alone lost nearly $1.1 billion, while total crypto fund outflows reached $1.73 billion, the largest weekly #withdrawal  since mid-November, according to CoinShares. The majority of that capital left U.S.-based products.

$BTC  Whales Accumulate While Retail Traders Exit, According to Glassnode Data    Glassnode data reveals a sharp split in behavior across $BTC  holder groups as prices continue to decline. Wallets holding 10,000 $BTC  or more are the only cohort currently in #accumulation , maintaining a neutral-to-slightly-positive balance trend since late November. Every other holder category is net selling.   Retail participants holding fewer than 10 $BTC  have been in persistent distribution for over a month. This group reflects continued risk aversion among smaller investors as $BTC  trades near $78,000, down sharply from its October all-time high of $126,000.   The number of unique entities holding at least 1,000 $BTC  has risen from 1,207 in October to 1,303 currently. This increase occurred entirely during the price #correction , indicating that larger players have been buying into weakness rather than reducing exposure.   Glassnode's Accumulation Trend Score measures relative behavior by wallet size, factoring in both balance and the amount of $BTC  acquired over the past 15 days. Scores near 1 indicate buying activity, while values closer to 0 signal selling. The largest whale cohort has remained near the buying end of this scale throughout the current drawdown.   Since $BTC  fell to $80,000 in late November, the price has largely traded within an $80,000 to $97,000 range through the end of January. During this consolidation window, #mega-whales  sustained a light accumulation phase while smaller holders continued to exit. Wallets holding at least 1,000 $BTC  are now back at December 2024 highs in terms of entity count.   The data paints a picture of supply absorption at the top end of the market. Large #Bitcoin  holders are absorbing coins that retail traders are offloading, a pattern that has historically appeared during the middle stages of #bull  market corrections before prices recover.

üìä Bitcoin ( $BTC  ) Monthly Returns: What the Data Really Says   This heatmap highlights a recurring truth about Bitcoin: returns are highly seasonal, but not random.  Historically, Q1 and Q4 have delivered the strongest upside, while mid-year months tend to be more mixed or corrective.  Key observations:  ‚Ä¢ February, March, April, October, and November stand out with the highest average returns. November in particular is exceptional, posting one of the highest average and median monthly performances across Bitcoin‚Äôs history.  ‚Ä¢ June, August, and September are structurally weaker. June often marks trend exhaustion, while August‚ÄìSeptember frequently act as consolidation or drawdown periods before Q4 volatility returns.  ‚Ä¢ Large green months often follow clusters of red months. Bitcoin rarely trends smoothly ‚Äî compression phases usually precede expansion.  ‚Ä¢ Volatility cuts both ways. Strong positive months don‚Äôt guarantee continuation, but historically they tend to appear after periods of pessimism rather than euphoria.  What this means for positioning:  This data doesn‚Äôt predict price direction, but it frames expectations. When the market enters historically strong months with depressed sentiment, risk-reward improves. Conversely, chasing strength during statistically weaker periods often leads to frustration.  Bitcoin isn‚Äôt random ‚Äî it‚Äôs cyclical. Those who understand the rhythm focus less on short-term noise and more on where they are in the calendar, the cycle, and sentiment curve.  Seasonality doesn‚Äôt replace analysis ‚Äî but ignoring it is leaving information on the table.  #BTC Price Analysis#  #Macro Insights#

In some cases, this concept perfectly predicts growth, in others, it doesn't, but it still ends up in the black. If the indicator BUYs, we buy; if the concept says SELLs, we sell, and we'll still make a profit. while headlines scream panic, crypto is trading at extremely low, oversold levels. Historically, these are exactly the conditions where opportunities emerge for those who look beyond short-term price action.
Panic rarely creates value.
But panic does create entry opportunities.

side by side with metals.
Here's the headline math: gold's market value jumped by roughly $2.2T in a single session.
That's almost 20x the entire market cap of ~
¬ßXRP, which sits near ~$103B. Even Bitcoin, valued around $1.7T, was eclipsed by gold's one-day gain. But this is where scale matters. Gold is massive. A relatively small percentage move in such a huge market turns into trillions on paper. That doesn't mean trillions of new money suddenly rushed in - it's just how big markets behave.
Crypto works differently. Smaller pools of capital can move prices much faster - up or down. That's why silver's sharp reversal and crypto's quiet reaction tell the same story: headline numbers look dramatic, but they don't equal destiny. The math is eye-catching - the context is everything.

Why is Bitcoin $BTC  price going down today? Bitcoin price is going down due to a confluence of extreme leverage liquidations and a mania meltdown in precious metals that is forcing traders to sell other assets to cover their losses.    Data from CoinGlass shows that the crypto market experienced $798 million in liquidations today, with most of the wipeout coming from highly leveraged bullish bets. Bitcoin alone accounted for over $200 million of those long liquidations.  Liquidation occurs when an exchange or broker is forced to close a trader‚Äôs position because the market moves against them and they no longer have enough margin to cover the risk. A majority of the wipeout from long positions occurs when an asset‚Äôs price faces a sudden, unexpected drop.   Exchanges are forced to close these bets, which in turn triggers a liquidity cascade that could continue to hurt prices.  This cascade of liquidations initially took hold over the weekend when more than $2.4 billion in bullish positions were wiped out, creating a climate of fear that continues to drive traders away from the market. #BTC Correction Incoming?#  $BTC  The sell-off was further exacerbated by a precious metals meltdown. Investors fear that he will aggressively shrink the Federal Reserve‚Äôs balance sheet and tighten liquidity, effectively removing the easy money environment that tends to support speculative assets like Bitcoin.  Meanwhile, unlike previous dips, Bitcoin‚Äôs sharp sell-off this time was shaped by a noticeable absence of buyers. Institutional interest in the legacy crypto asset has cooled significantly, with spot Bitcoin ETFs recording over 1.6 billion in net outflows throughout January.

Converting Peruvian Soles (PEN) to US Dollars (USD) is a common need for travelers, businesses, freelancers, and investors connected to Peru‚Äôs economy. While the process seems straightforward, the final amount received can vary widely depending on the conversion method used.  Why the Peruvian Sol Is Important? The Peruvian Sol is one of Latin America‚Äôs more stable currencies, supported by disciplined monetary policy and strong commodity exports such as copper and gold. This stability makes PEN reliable for local transactions, while USD remains essential for international trade, savings, and cross-border payments.  How Much Does the PEN/USD Rate Vary by Transaction Type?  Exchange rates differ across cash, bank transfers, cards, and digital platforms. Cash exchanges often include wide spreads and hidden fees. Bank transfers usually offer better pricing but may involve processing delays. Card transactions tend to use competitive network rates, though foreign transaction fees can reduce the final value.  How Can Crypto Exchanges Help With PEN/USD Conversion?  Crypto exchanges provide an alternative route for converting PEN to USD value. Platforms like Bitget and Binance allow users to access market-driven pricing and convert funds into USD-pegged stablecoins or assets such as Bitcoin $BTC  . BTC‚Äôs global liquidity and 24/7 trading can help reduce spreads and speed up settlement for crypto-native users.  Conclusion Choosing the right conversion method matters. While banks and cash services remain common, crypto platforms and Bitcoin-based tools are increasingly offering faster, more transparent alternatives for converting PEN to USD. What makes Gold and Silver crash?   $XAUt  Gold and silver usually crash when macroeconomic conditions shift against safe-haven demand. Rising interest rates and a stronger U.S. dollar are two of the biggest triggers when yields go up, holding non-yielding assets like gold and silver becomes less attractive, leading to sell-offs. Central bank policy signals, especially from the U.S. Federal Reserve, can quickly flip market sentiment. In addition, sudden improvements in risk appetite (when investors move back into stocks or crypto) and large institutional profit-taking after extended rallies can cause sharp pullbacks in both metals.  $BTC    The benefits of trading the uptrend actively   Actively trading gold and silver during an uptrend allows traders to ride momentum instead of predicting tops or bottoms. When metals are trending, price tends to respect higher highs and higher lows, creating repeated opportunities for entries on pullbacks and breakouts. Active uptrend trading also helps manage risk better traders can trail stops, lock in profits, and re-enter as momentum continues. On highly liquid platforms, volatility becomes an advantage, giving frequent chances to compound gains rather than waiting for long-term appreciation.   How crypto traders use Bitget TradFi to build their portfolio   Many crypto traders diversify into Bitget TradFi to capitalize on gold and silver trends without leaving a familiar trading environment. Since crypto traders are already skilled at momentum trading, leverage management, and 24/7 markets, they apply the same strategies to metals‚Äîespecially during strong macro-driven trends. By trading gold and silver alongside crypto, traders reduce overexposure to one asset class while still staying active in trending markets. This diversification helps smooth portfolio performance, capture gains during metal uptrends, and build a more resilient portfolio across crypto and traditional assets.
